tips.tip: Aspergillus after MAC is becoming increasingly common. One positive sputum does NOT mean infection - you need multiple positive samples PLUS aspergillus-specific IgE and IgM blood tests to confirm true infection. Many patients have aspergillus in sputum without infection requiring treatment. Doctors monitor unless symptoms develop.
tips.notes: Caroline Nixon's diagnostic criteria. Rick Stelzer notes aspergillus increasingly common post-MAC. Cavities left by MAC create environment for fungal ball formation.

tips.tip: Aspergillus treatment options: Voriconazole (first-line), Posaconazole (better tolerated if voriconazole causes reactions), Isavuconazole (newer), or Cresemba (newest but expensive with limited insurance coverage). All require 2-3+ years of treatment. Weekly blood tests monitor liver enzymes. Dosage can be reduced if liver enzymes elevate while maintaining effectiveness (e.g., 300mg to 200mg posaconazole).
tips.notes: Rick on voriconazole 2.5+ years. Victoria tolerated posaconazole better. Ivette reduced dosage successfully. Jo Ann stopped isavuconazole due to liver + drug interactions.

tips.tip: ABPA (Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis) vs regular aspergillus infection: ABPA = allergic reaction causing lung damage, diagnosed by skyrocketing EOS and IgE values. Request CBC with differentials (absolute EOS) and IgE blood tests if suspect ABPA. Dupixent works 'outstanding' for ABPA allergic reaction. Some patients start with aspergillus, it morphs into NTM.
tips.notes: RB Sylvester's ABPA diagnosis at Northwestern. Dupixent addressed allergic reaction and lung damage. Key: ABPA is allergic, not infectious aspergillosis.

tips.tip: Aspergillus monitoring protocol: If asymptomatic (no cough increase, no hemoptysis), many doctors 'don't bother' treating and just monitor with sputum cultures every 6 months. Treatment only when symptomatic or CT shows progression. Some aspergillus goes away on its own with good airway clearance. For persistent dry cough variant: low-dose Breo inhalant + Pepcid works ('does the trick' for 2+ years).
tips.notes: Casey's aspergillus resolved without treatment. Anonymous patient's dry cough treated with Breo+Pepcid. Marie L's pulmonologist doesn't treat without symptoms.

tips.tip: Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Most common coinfection. Treated only when symptomatic (NOT asymptomatic colonization). Oral options: Ciprofloxacin 500mg 2x/day 10-21 days (most common), Levaquin 750mg 14 days, or Doxycycline. Inhaled options: Tobramycin 28 days on/28 days off (standard), inhaled Colistin 3 months. Pseudomonas often comes back after treatment - 'loves lungs,' difficult to eradicate permanently.
tips.notes: Julia treated 'more than a few times' over 8 years. Bonnie: 'that bug loves my lungs.' Diane: 3-4 treatments, never got rid of it. Levaquin/cipro most common oral.

tips.tip: C. diff risk with pseudomonas treatment: Ciprofloxacin can cause C. difficile (25 lbs weight loss documented). Preventive strategies: Take probiotics daily + yogurt during treatment. Doxycycline has LOWER C. diff risk than cipro. If previous C. diff history, ask ID doctor about prophylactic Vancomycin during pseudomonas treatment to prevent recurrence.
tips.notes: Lesley developed C. diff after cipro+tobramycin combo. ID prescribed prophylactic vancomycin for future treatments. Multiple patients take probiotics preventively.

tips.tip: Inhaled Tobramycin paradox: Makes you feel WORSE (increased coughing, shortness of breath, lungs feel heavy/full, exhausting) but PREVENTS exacerbations and keeps you out of hospital. Coughing increases immediately after nebulizing, lasts 1.5-4 hours. Doctor's explanation: coughing IS the benefit ('airway clearing'). Sputum lightens in color (good sign) even though volume may not change. Some patients tolerate better off-treatment.
tips.notes: Barbara Stein: exhausting coughing but no exacerbations for year on treatment. Quinn: lungs heavy/full, short of breath on treatment but feels better off. Anonymous: kidney issues from Tobi.

tips.tip: Pseudomonas treatment for exacerbations only (not colonization): Treat only when symptomatic (increased malaise, low fever, more coughing/sputum, fatigue). Cipro 500mg 2x/day for 2 weeks, maybe twice yearly. Between exacerbations, daily 7% saline nebulization usually keeps under control without antibiotics. Difference: Aeruginosa type is most pathogenic; 'not aeruginosa' types less aggressive.
tips.notes: Patricia: treated twice yearly for exacerbations only. Shannon: 7% saline keeps controlled, doxycycline when symptomatic. Cat G: aeruginosa requires susceptibility testing, other strains not pathogenic.

tips.tip: Levaquin (Levofloxacin) tendon rupture risk: 750mg Levaquin effective for pseudomonas (14 days) but STRONG antibiotic causing body aches, dizziness, tendon issues with repeated use. Some patients specifically seek pseudomonas drugs that 'do not have tendon issues/ruptures.' Short 5-day courses may work for flareups. Might kill some MAC while treating pseudomonas (ID doctor noted this benefit).
tips.notes: Bonnie: more side effects with repeated Levaquin use - body aches, dizziness. Michele: 5 days worked. Tendon rupture concern prompts search for alternatives.

tips.tip: Bacterial colonization 'musical chairs': Multiple bacteria can colonize bronchiectasis lungs - one 'nudges out' another. Achromobacter xylosidans is antibiotic-RESISTANT, always shows up. Bactrim 10 days 'bats it down,' then pseudomonas 'nudged it out of the way' - now Achromobacter lurking but not showing in culture. Hard to keep track. Most cannot be completely eradicated, just managed.
tips.notes: Michele Burke's 'funny' observation about bacterial competition. Reflects reality that bronchiectasis = damaged environment hospitable to multiple opportunistic pathogens cycling.

tips.tip: Staph colonization in BE/MAC patients: 'Not uncommon' per National Jewish pulmonologists/ID doctors. DO NOT TREAT unless experiencing bad symptoms (increased fatigue, more sputum than usual). Antibiotics: Doxycycline or Bactrim 14-28 days if symptomatic. Twice-daily 7% saline usually keeps under control. Staph is 'pain in neck to get rid of' - often returns. Won't cause cavities (less concerning than MAC).
tips.notes: Shannon's NJH doctors don't treat unless symptomatic. Kate's pulmonologist: 'pain in neck,' leave alone if no symptoms. Whitney/Mona: multiple treatment rounds, no success.

tips.tip: Nasal staph treatment: Antibiotic cream applied inside BOTH nostrils can eliminate staph colonization since nostrils are entry point. Stanford ID doctor protocol - patient has not had staph return in 15+ years after nasal treatment. However, this may only work if staph hasn't reached lungs yet (unclear if works for lung-colonized staph).
tips.notes: Cecilia Peabody's long-term success with nasal antibiotic cream. Anonymous asked if it works for lung colonization - no response yet. Preventive strategy worth trying.

tips.tip: Haemophilus influenzae (H.I.): Does NOT mean pneumonia despite name. Not contagious to people with normal lungs. Treated with Doxycycline, Cipro 15-20 days, Augmentin, or Levaquin. First-time 'heavy growth' affects energy severely. Chronic coughing may stop after treatment. Cipro 'might kill some MAC' while treating H.I. (ID doctor comment). H.I. is same bug causing ear infections in kids - 'less impressive bacteria.'
tips.notes: Anonymous patients: severe energy impact with heavy growth, chronic cough stopped after treatment. One patient's flu-like symptoms (fever, junky sputum) resolved with levaquin.

tips.tip: E. coli in lungs (rare): Typically from ASPIRATION due to esophageal dysmotility or GERD. All GI tests can be normal (no GERD, normal endoscopy, normal pH monitoring, normal manometry) yet barium swallow shows dysmotility. Clue: Lifelong sensation of food/drinks needing 'extra moment to go all the way down' (patient thought this was normal!). Extremely difficult to eradicate.
tips.notes: Juli's case discussed at 1st North American BE/NTM Symposium. 13 rounds antibiotics since Dec 2022. Levofloxacin works best - felt like 'normal human' for 1-2 months but returns.

tips.tip: E. coli treatment cycle: Levofloxacin most effective - restores energy, better breathing, feels healthy, lungs sound good, STOPS producing sputum during airway clearance (amazing outcome!). Lasts 1-2 months then slowly declines. 6 different antibiotics tried over 13 treatment rounds. Also found: Amoxicillin + candida albicans coinfection treated together. 'It just won't die.'
tips.notes: Juli's detailed experience. Emma Biggs also had E. coli + MAC + candida - amoxicillin used. Consultant optimistic about eradication but extremely challenging.

tips.tip: Klebsiella pneumoniae: Not uncommon pulmonary pathogen in bronchiectasis. Treated with Augmentin (course length unclear - 10 days to 2-3 weeks reported). Often clears but may show up in small quantities on subsequent cultures without requiring re-treatment. Culture includes antibiotic sensitivity testing to guide treatment. Less concerning than MAC.
tips.notes: Linda Nichols (retired lab scientist): not uncommon, culture has sensitivity testing. Anonymous: cleared twice with Augmentin. Patricia: severe 10-12 years ago, now appears occasionally without treatment needed.

tips.tip: Serratia marcescens: Doctors 'don't bother' treating unless additional symptoms beyond baseline. Treated with Cipro 500mg 2x/day for 10 days if symptomatic. Difficult to eradicate. Many patients culture it without treatment. Goes away with regular airway clearance in some cases. Cleared incidentally during pseudomonas antibiotic treatments. Surveillance every 6 months so doctor knows which antibiotic to prescribe if become symptomatic.
tips.notes: Marie's MAC specialist 'doesn't bother with it.' Leslie no longer cultures after starting airway clearance. Barbara cleared with pseudomonas treatments. Marie L: surveillance approach.

tips.tip: Pseudomonas can cause cavities (not just MAC/NTM): Patient has 2 cavities in upper right lung with only pseudomonas aeruginosa (no MAC/NTM) on bronchoscopy culture. Doctor monitors with CT every 6 months but says no treatment necessary if using daily nebulizer. Challenges assumption that only mycobacteria cause cavitation.
tips.notes: Penny Raether's case - final cultures after bronchoscopy showed ONLY pseudomonas but has cavities. No responses yet to question about pseudomonas causing cavities.

key_insights: Coinfections are the NORM, not exception, in bronchiectasis/NTM: 'Not uncommon' per National Jewish experts. Damaged airways create hospitable environment for multiple opportunistic bacterial and fungal pathogens. Pattern: MAC treatment → lung damage/cavities → aspergillus colonization → pseudomonas cycles → staph colonization. Serial infections, not simultaneous necessarily.

Treatment philosophy: SYMPTOMS over culture results. Core principle across all coinfections: Asymptomatic colonization (bacteria present without symptoms) does NOT require treatment. Treat only when symptomatic: increased fatigue, fever, more coughing/sputum, feeling worse. Exception: First-time heavy growth may warrant treatment even if asymptomatic to prevent progression.

Aspergillus post-MAC pattern: 'Increasingly common' phenomenon. MAC creates cavities → aspergillus forms fungal ball in cavity. Requires 2-3+ YEARS of antifungals (not months like bacterial infections). Weekly liver monitoring essential. Multiple drug options if first causes reactions. ABPA (allergic aspergillosis) requires different treatment (Dupixent) than infectious aspergillosis (voriconazole).

Pseudomonas: The persistent nemesis. 'That bug LOVES my lungs.' Most common bacterial coinfection. Extremely difficult to eradicate permanently - comes back repeatedly. Treatment paradox: Inhaled Tobramycin makes you feel WORSE (exhausting coughing, SOB, heavy lungs) but prevents exacerbations and hospitalizations. Coughing IS the therapeutic mechanism ('airway clearing'). Patients must choose: feel better short-term off drugs OR prevent exacerbations long-term on drugs.

C. diff as treatment complication: Fluoroquinolones (cipro, levaquin) for pseudomonas carry C. difficile risk - can cause severe weight loss (25 lbs documented). Prevention strategies critical: Daily probiotics + yogurt during treatment. Prophylactic vancomycin if previous C. diff history. Doxycycline lower C. diff risk alternative. Risk-benefit calculation required.

Bacterial musical chairs phenomenon: Multiple bacteria 'compete' in damaged bronchiectasis lungs. One gets 'nudged out' by another. Achromobacter lurks when pseudomonas present. Hard to keep track. Most CANNOT be completely eradicated - just managed. Surveillance cultures every 6 months track which bacteria present so doctor knows antibiotic sensitivities when symptoms develop.

Rare but challenging: E. coli in lungs from aspiration. Requires discovering hidden dysmotility (patient thought lifelong swallowing quirk was 'normal'). 13 antibiotic rounds over 2+ years, still returns after 1-2 months. Symposium-level case complexity. Levofloxacin provides best temporary relief. 'It just won't die' - reflects extreme difficulty eradicating GI bacteria from respiratory tract.

Staph colonization management: NJH experts don't treat unless symptomatic. 'Pain in neck to get rid of' - often returns after doxycycline/Bactrim. Daily 7% saline usually keeps controlled. Won't cause cavities (less dangerous than MAC). Novel strategy: Nasal antibiotic cream (nostrils = entry point) - 15+ years success in one patient.

Diagnostic precision matters: One positive aspergillus culture ≠ infection (need multiple + IgE/IgM blood tests). Pseudomonas aeruginosa (pathogenic) ≠ other pseudomonas types (not usually pathogenic). Haemophilus ≠ pneumonia despite name. Serratia difficult to eradicate but often benign. Klebsiella common, usually clears. Antibiotic sensitivity testing guides treatment - not all antibiotics work for all bacteria.

common_questions.question: I just cultured aspergillus - does this mean I have an infection that needs treatment?
common_questions.answer: Not necessarily. ONE positive aspergillus culture does NOT mean infection. You need MULTIPLE positive sputum samples PLUS aspergillus-specific IgE and IgM blood tests to confirm true infection. Many BE/MAC patients have aspergillus in sputum without it being an infection - it's just colonization. Doctors monitor with repeat cultures and only treat if you become symptomatic (increased cough, hemoptysis) or CT shows progression. Some aspergillus goes away on its own with good airway clearance.

common_questions.question: What's the difference between regular aspergillus infection and ABPA?
common_questions.answer: ABPA (Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis) is an ALLERGIC REACTION to aspergillus that causes lung damage, NOT an infection. Diagnosed by skyrocketing EOS and IgE blood values (request CBC with differentials for absolute EOS + IgE test). ABPA is treated with Dupixent (works 'outstanding' for the allergic reaction) not antifungal medications. Regular aspergillus infection is treated with voriconazole, posaconazole, or other antifungals for 2-3+ years.

common_questions.question: How long does aspergillus treatment take and what are my medication options?
common_questions.answer: 2-3+ YEARS minimum (much longer than bacterial infections). Options: (1) Voriconazole - first-line, (2) Posaconazole - better tolerated if voriconazole causes reactions, can reduce from 300mg to 200mg if liver enzymes elevate, (3) Isavuconazole - newer option but may cause liver issues + drug interactions, (4) Cresemba - newest but very expensive with limited insurance coverage. All require weekly blood tests to monitor liver enzymes. Treatment typically continues until cultures negative for extended period.

common_questions.question: Should I treat my pseudomonas if I don't have symptoms?
common_questions.answer: Generally NO. Core principle: Treat pseudomonas only when SYMPTOMATIC (increased malaise, low fever, more coughing/sputum, fatigue). Asymptomatic colonization doesn't require treatment. Between flareups, daily 7% saline nebulization usually keeps it under control. Exception: First-time heavy growth might warrant treatment even without major symptoms. Pseudomonas aeruginosa (most pathogenic type) more likely to need treatment than 'not aeruginosa' types.

common_questions.question: What antibiotic works best for pseudomonas and how long do I take it?
common_questions.answer: ORAL options: Ciprofloxacin 500mg twice daily for 10-21 days (most common), Levaquin 750mg for 14 days (stronger but more side effects), or Doxycycline (lower C. diff risk). INHALED options: Tobramycin 28 days on/28 days off (standard long-term), or inhaled Colistin for 3 months. Culture should include sensitivity testing to confirm which antibiotics your pseudomonas responds to. Pseudomonas often comes back after treatment - extremely difficult to eradicate permanently.

common_questions.question: Why does inhaled Tobramycin make me feel so much worse?
common_questions.answer: This is EXPECTED and actually therapeutic! Tobramycin increases coughing (exhausting 1.5-4 hours after nebulizing), makes lungs feel heavy/full, causes shortness of breath. Doctor's explanation: The increased coughing IS the benefit - it's 'airway clearing.' Your sputum should lighten in color (good sign) even if volume doesn't decrease. The paradox: Feel worse on treatment BUT prevents exacerbations and keeps you out of hospital. Must choose: better short-term comfort off drugs vs. preventing hospitalizations on drugs.

common_questions.question: How do I prevent C. diff when taking cipro or levaquin for pseudomonas?
common_questions.answer: Prevention strategies: (1) Take daily probiotics + eat yogurt throughout antibiotic course, (2) Consider Doxycycline instead - has LOWER C. diff risk than fluoroquinolones, (3) If you've had C. diff before, ask your ID doctor about taking prophylactic Vancomycin during pseudomonas treatment to prevent recurrence. C. diff can cause severe complications (25 lbs weight loss documented). Taking probiotics is standard practice for many patients on repeated antibiotic courses.

common_questions.question: Should I treat my staph colonization?
common_questions.answer: Only if SYMPTOMATIC (increased fatigue, more sputum than usual). National Jewish pulmonologists and ID doctors say staph colonization is 'not uncommon' in BE/MAC patients and do NOT treat unless experiencing bad symptoms. Staph is 'pain in neck to get rid of' and often returns even after Doxycycline or Bactrim 14-28 days. Daily 7% saline usually keeps it controlled. Good news: Staph won't cause cavities like MAC does, so less concerning. Novel prevention: Antibiotic cream inside both nostrils (nasal entry point) - one patient hasn't had staph return in 15+ years.

common_questions.question: What does it mean if I keep culturing different bacteria over time?
common_questions.answer: Normal for bronchiectasis lungs - this is 'bacterial musical chairs.' Multiple bacteria colonize damaged airways and one can 'nudge out' another. For example: Achromobacter present, then pseudomonas 'nudges it out,' but Achromobacter still 'lurking' even when not showing in culture. Hard to keep track. Reality: Most bacteria CANNOT be completely eradicated from bronchiectasis lungs, just managed. This is why doctors recommend surveillance cultures every 6 months - so they know which bacteria are present and their antibiotic sensitivities when you become symptomatic.

common_questions.question: Is haemophilus influenzae (H.I.) pneumonia? Am I contagious?
common_questions.answer: NO, it does NOT mean pneumonia despite the name. And NO, you are NOT contagious to people with normal lungs. H.I. is the same bacteria that causes ear infections in kids - considered 'less impressive bacteria.' Treated with Doxycycline, Cipro 15-20 days, Augmentin, or Levaquin if symptomatic. First-time heavy growth can severely affect energy, but chronic coughing often stops after treatment. Bonus: Cipro treating H.I. 'might kill some MAC' according to one ID doctor.

common_questions.question: I cultured klebsiella pneumoniae - how serious is this?
common_questions.answer: Not uncommon pulmonary pathogen in bronchiectasis and less concerning than MAC. Usually treated with Augmentin for 10 days to 2-3 weeks (your culture will include antibiotic sensitivity testing to guide choice). Klebsiella often clears with treatment, though may show up in small quantities on subsequent cultures without requiring re-treatment unless you're symptomatic. One patient had severe case 10-12 years ago (2-3 weeks Augmentin) and it now only appears occasionally without needing treatment.

common_questions.question: Should I worry about serratia in my sputum?
common_questions.answer: Probably not unless symptomatic. Multiple pulmonologists including MAC specialists say they 'don't bother' treating serratia unless you have additional symptoms beyond baseline. If symptomatic: Cipro 500mg twice daily for 10 days. Serratia is difficult to eradicate but often doesn't cause problems. Some patients find it disappears with regular airway clearance. Others have it cleared incidentally during antibiotic treatment for pseudomonas. Doctors typically do surveillance cultures every 6 months to track it and know antibiotic sensitivities if you later become symptomatic.

common_questions.question: How did I get E. coli in my LUNGS?
common_questions.answer: Almost always from ASPIRATION due to esophageal dysmotility or GERD. The tricky part: All your GI tests can be NORMAL (endoscopy, pH monitoring, manometry) but barium swallow may show the dysmotility. Key clue: Lifelong sensation that food/drinks need 'extra moment to go all the way down' - patients think this is normal but it's actually dysmotility allowing micro-aspirations. E. coli in lungs is rare and extremely difficult to eradicate (13 antibiotic rounds over 2+ years documented). Levofloxacin works best but infection returns after 1-2 months.

common_questions.question: Can pseudomonas cause lung cavities like MAC does?
common_questions.answer: Possibly yes, though this challenges conventional teaching. One patient's bronchoscopy showed ONLY pseudomonas aeruginosa (no MAC/NTM) but has 2 cavities in upper right lung. Doctor monitoring with CT every 6 months. This suggests pseudomonas may be more damaging than typically thought, though more research needed. Traditional teaching says only mycobacteria (MAC, abscessus) cause cavitation, but clinical cases suggest pseudomonas may also contribute to cavity formation in some patients.
